author: avri

description.text:
This is a model of the Mission San Juan Capistrano in California.  It is by no means to scale or even accurate in its design.  Its meant to simply represent a close rendering of the mission.  
I designed this for my daughter and Its going to make a great addition to her 4th grade mission project.
Update: I have added the side buildings and the old destroyed mission we created as well.  Enjoy.

A printer made of surplus 30x30x3 profiles, linear shafts and 1605 ball screw. The frame is really massive and includes solid alu bearing mounts for XY rods and Z ballscrew. Clear covers are made from 4mm PC sheet.
The Z stepper is a high torque version (55Ncm)
Print area is similar to the UM2 Extended. Thanks to Jasonatepaint for inspiration!

title: Clip for Thor Force Knee Pads

description.text:
I got these knee pads for cheap at a used gear store because they didn't have the little black plastic clips for two of the straps.  I knew I could probably 3D print them. This sure isn't the prettiest project after melting the clip a little but it makes my safety equipment work and that's all that matters to me.  
I took the grain direction of the printing process into mind with this part, but it makes post processing necessary.  Once this part has been printed you must heat the base of the hook shape and twist it 90 degrees.  I used a lighter and gently flashed it with heat several times to loosen the area up and then twisted and cooled under cold water.  This would be much nicer looking if a different source of heat was used.   I also did a little light trimming with a knife to round out a few rough edges

heat base of hook
twist
cool
trim edges with knife
use

author: Soutie

description.text: Based on Rubbermaid FastTrack Clip by dhulihan, I added a loop so I could hang items that have hooks (bungie cords, etc.).

Build this Frame for my DIY Banggood Laser. The Original Frame with the Sliders are only for slow movements and its also very inaccurate. With the rods and Bearings its possible to engrave/cut much faster with much better results. The Stepper Motors are now fixed on the Frame, not on the Moving Parts (less weight on parts which moves)
Used some LM8uu Bearings and 8mm rods, which are laying around.
Easy scaling of the X and Y lenght. Only your Rods deciding the Build Volume
The whole System can mount on AluExtrusions or on a Woodplate.
To build these you need:
some M3 screws, 3x M4 screws (for the pulleys) and 8x M5 screws (for the 4 corners), also some M3/M4/M5 Nuts
4x Lm8uu ballbearings for the Y Axis,
2x lm8luu for the X Axis (Laser Carrier),
4x 8mm rods (in my case for the A3 Laser engraver 2x41cm and 2x55cm)
6x flanged ball bearings 4x8x3 or 3 other pulleys for the gt2 belts
gt2 belt (3x50cm for A3) the electrical components for a laserengraver. I used it from my banggood engraver
3 Nema17 Motors, mainboard, laser unit etc... File descripition:
Buil Plate: All Files which fits on a 190x175mm BuildPlate. Only print once
complete Model: only for viewing. Do not Print this!
all Parts are available in seperate File.

Printer:

Hypercore

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,18

Infill:

35

Notes: Print with Support could be usefull, but also difficult in Screwholes.

title: Filament Feed Tube Holder/Clamp for Maker Bot Replicator 2X

description.text:
I don't know about everyone else, but the feed tubes on my Maker Bot Replicator 2X would constantly pop out. So I've created a simple and aesthetically pleasing clip-on clamp.   
Both .thing files are ready to go, the "Tube Holder With DualX Letters" is a dual extrude print and will require a dual extruder printer. I also posted the STL files for the single extrude model.  
Enjoy!

comments.text: What infill density is recommended?  Does the arms need to have some flex to grab what they clip to?

I'd love to print this, but I can't get the main model (The part without the letters) to appear in preview or print in simplify3d. I've tried everything I can think of, but with no luck.
Looks awesome though!

comments.author: DrRickRussell

comments.text:
This looks to be exactly what I am looking for. However, despite the fact that I have dual extruders I would have liked to print this quickly without the lettering. Although the STL files supplied suggest options to print without lettering, those STL files appear to just turn the lettering into the same colour as the rest of the object - which means that the replicator is spending inordinate amounts of time tracing round the letters that you can't see on completion as it builds the print.
What is needed is an STL file which has the design WITHOUT the lettering. Otherwise, excellent job.
comments.author: JoeSoap583

comments.text: I like it. Question though, are the tubes in there tight? I thought the tubes need to be able to freely rotate within the guide?
comments.author: rubb3rtoe

comments.text: It holds the guide tubes quite snug.  I felt mine while printing and there was no movement, but I just finished a 3 hr long print and had no problems.

title: Laser Vent 4" Duct Adapter for K40

description.text:
This is a simple adapter that slides into the mounting brackets on the back of a cheap K40 laser cutter so you can attach a 4" dryer duct. You need to cut a piece of 1/16" (1.5mm) craft foam to act as a gasket, and affix it the the flat part of the adapter for a snug fit. I've printed and tested the fit on this one, and it did fit with a notch cut to clear the screw heads above and below the exhaust vent. I've just updated this Thing with three more files. V2 reflects a 2.5mm thinner base, for better screw clearance. I've split it into two pieces, too, pA and pB, for smaller printers or reduced warping and support material. New update: I added an upwards-facing version of the duct. It exists as a full duct or split to avoid supports. It requires a fairly large bed, so you might have to split it yourself to print it on an 8-inch (200-mm) bed. To do (if requested):
  • Reduce the length of the duct connection space to save time and material. Currently, it works just fine, though.

This thing is a Cairo pentagonal tiling of pentagons projected onto the surface of a torus.
Find the openscad code at http://www.whitehydra.com/cairo_torus.html
It was printed on a makerbot replicator at school, with no supports.

First, I coordinatized the vertices of a single hexagon, plus the five lines inside. The coordinatization was in R2 in the x-y plane. I defined lines connecting each vertex with a loop that translated multiple spheres along the lines. I used the vector equation of a line: V = v0 + t(v1 - v0), where v0 and v1 are the two vertices on either end of the line. I re-parameterized each line into toroidal coordinates in order to pop each line out onto the surface of a torus. After I had the first pattern on the torus, I was able to rotate and copy the pattern all the way around the torus.

comments.text: This is very cool! What kind of software did you use to create the list of vectors?
comments.author: fmargueirat

comments.text: There are a couple more images for it now to help explain. I coordinatized each vertex of the tiling in the xy plane, then paramaterized a vector equation of the line between each vertex, then wrote a loop in openscad to echo 10 points along each paramaterized line to the console. I copied and pasted this first list into the editor and wrote another loop that took each xy point and transformed it into toroidal coordinates and echoed it into the console again. I copied and pasted this second list back into the editor and wrote a third loop that took the hull() between each pair of points to give a nice smooth appearance. I can upload each page of my calculations if you want to check them out. openscad can handle nearly everything I want to do.

When I decided to enter the remix challenge I chose to remix a 3D model that could help people. I decided that instead of remaking the "paste pusher" I would remix it for those with a disability limiting their bimanual arm coordination. It was important that the model be easy to assemble with one hand, yet able to be customized by the user. I started this remix by building a stand designed for accessories to snap onto. Then I designed two types of cup holders, a stand with four toothbrush holders, a bin for dental floss or other items of ones choice and an area to hold the toothbrush while the user applies the toothpaste; as well as, incorporating the "paste pusher" in the center of the stand to push the toothpaste to the open end of the tube. In conclusion, My goal was to take an existing 3D design and remix this design for use by those individuals with a disability that limits their ability to use two hands to prepare their toothbrush for brushing their teeth. Video Link: https://youtu.be/Ua4R7C1YlFM

update: 12/30/16 I take it back, this case fits very well with rigid back piece and Semi flex front. the newest picture is wood PLA and white TPU 95A and it looks an fits perfect! this is a case for the Moto Z Phone with the Incipio battery pack mod. the origional phone case that I designed for just the phone is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752345 this case, In my opinion is not as good as the original for fitment issues, only because the shape of the new back piece. but it works well if you print the back in rigid PLA or ABS, and print the front piece in either Semi-Flex or TPU 95A (flexible polyurethane). the case on the left in the photos is PLA back and TPU front. Whereas the case on the right is NinjaFlex TPE back and ABS front. if anything, for this case, stay away from the NinjaFlex, its too flexible! Use TPU 95A, and if you haven't use it before, its easier to print than NinjaFlex and its much cheaper!!! still I don't go over 15 mm/s for TPU. Scale both pieces of the model to 101% in the X and Y direction for proper fitment.

comments.author: andrescoma90

comments.text:
Like the phone doesn't even fit into the back piece? or the case doesn't fit together? I would suggest using PLA for the back piece (often stronger than ABS unless your using a heated enclosure due to poor layer adhesion and dimensional inaccuracy), there aren't as many weak places for this case once it is assembled on the phone. Did you use TPU (thermoplastic polyurethane) or Semi-Flex for the front part of the case? the case wont work unless you print one of the two pieces in a non rigid material, and I suggest that the front is printed flexible. an other reason to use PLA is so that you can crank up your part cooling fan and print the trapezoidal tabs really cleanly. the overhang is intense and the outside perimeter should be printed slowly. good luck and please post your make!
PS you could try 102% but that ended up printing too large on my machine and the phone wouldn't stay in place. 101% worked perfect for me: Back - (wood PLA), Front - White TPU, 0.5mm nozzle and 0.1mm layer height.

title: Pendant Lamp Ceiling Fixture
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A pretty simple bracket/wire clamp I made for a barn chandelier project in the basement. I wanted the pendants to hang straight down, so this allowed me to place the pendants and hold a bend in the wire.
For my install the pendants were pretty close to the low ceilings, but the height is easily adjustable.
I used fabric covered wire with an outer diameter of 6mm for this project.

author: jpacek

description.text:
Product link https://ru.aliexpress.com/item/4-3-Inch-Car-Vehicles-LCD-TFT-Screen-Display-Rearview-Reversing-Monitor-480x272/32701574180.html
Mount instead mirror of driver.

This is a demo object for a universal connection priciple. Holding together multiple parts (reversibly) usually requires screws springs or magnets.
But there is yet another method! By using the next connection pin to prevent the former from sliding out one can e.g. use just only one magnet at the last connection pin to hold a whole structure together. This is a special case of a great class of structures. If one pin locks multiple pins one gains a branching tree structure (topologically).
It should be possible to extend this principle to two or three dimenstions. CALLENGE!
With usage of branching the hole circumference or surface enclosing an area or volume filled with lots of elements could be locked at one single point. In an other context: Block based "Modular Molecular Composite Nanosystems"
out of stuctural DNA nanortechnology (DNA Bricks & co) as presented here
http://metamodern.com/2008/11/10/modular-molecular-composite-nanosystems/
may help us gaining robotic (more generally stereotactic) control at the nanocosmos. In that respect an interesting question is:
Would it be possible to construct a linkage / placement mechanism composed out of a few hundred standard blocks of a vew dozen types that can assamble a great range of structures out of those same blocks including a copies of itself? Creating and handling standard blocks may be easier than having a multitude of objects that each require special treatment in synthetisation and assembly (or may not). A hirachical locking structure of molecular blocks in machine phase (~= stuck to a place not brownian tumbling) makes accidental breaking of connections (that otherwise would only be held together by VdW force) more unlikely. The downside: building rods this way introduces compliance or even backlash that adds up proportional to the number of stacked elements. In advanced atomically precise products this connection principle in its generalized form will undoubtably play an important role.
Tipp: For disassembly of the assembled stack the small blade of a swiss army knive is useful.

title: Iphone SE / 5 / 5S Charging dock(standard apple lightning cable)

description.text:
Just made a Iphone 5S charging dock for my girlfriend. Feel free to remix this, I would like to see new idea's! Have fun with it!
There is a model that fits the iphone without case and there is a model made with some extra space(2mm) and a higher lightning connector for use with a case!

Just uploaded a V2 with some improvements. Changelog:

  • New bottom for improved cable management!

    • Slightly higher base to improve cable management underneath.
    • Slightly smaller connector hole for a tighter fit of the cable.
    • Put some 45 degree chamfers underneath to prevent the cable from damaging.

  • Improved some fillets for a better overall look!

  • Smaller speaker hole!
    • Better look
    • Better sound(louder then normal speaker :O)

title: Purple Baron Carousel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Purple Baron Carousel When I saw for the first time the Hand Cranked Vinyl Player by Oana I immediately thought that it was a perfect starting point for a carousel! And why not realising a carousel with cork biplanes?! Turning the crank makes the cork airplanes take-off. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tPV_APtKH7U

Printer:

Original Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Equal or less than 200 um for better results

Infill:

20%

Notes: I remixed the baseplate and some gears.
After some tweaking with an x-acto kife the baseplate, the stems and the upper gear will combine nicely. Have a look at the photos for proper connections.
Remember to keep the pieces connecting to the biplanes turn freely!
Some glue is needed as for the original Hand Cranked Vynil Player design.
The propeller needs a M3 6mm screw (or any small screw) for connection.
For better results and easier build up, print with at least 200um resolution. Have fun and let the biplanes fly high! Update 07/02/2017
I uploaded an easier-to-print version of the longest objects in Set03. They are tall parts with small footprint and can be tricky to print. The supports prevent them from falling off. Remove them before the final build-up. Update 11/02/2017
Despite double checking, it seems that the Box and the Stem STL files, that are difficult (to impossible) to slice if you are not using Slic3r. Sorry for the issue and many thanks to @geirskogul for reporting back! The corrected files are online and ready to be printed!
If you still experience issues slicing in Simplify3D the Box file, just click on Mesh->Separate Connected Surfaces. It should then slice without any problem!

comments.text:
Hi! Printing long pieces can always be tricky.
The first layer is mostrly important. Try to decrease the printing speed, increase the bed temperature (from 50 to 55°C should be enough) and consider using Raft support. I will upload a version of the long tallest pieces set with supports included, just to have a simpler printing experience! Just remove the supports before the build up.

comments.author: Scalone

comments.text: Oh! I had a similar problem with ad early print of the design. I was actually using a low-quality  PLA and when I decided to change to a good one, the print came up flawlessly. You may try to enable Z-Hop in your slicing software, decreasing the printing speed a little bit to improve layer strengt and increase the wall thickness. It may also depend on room temperature, since it may effect layer bonding.

title: Anet A8 extruder LED strip light mount

description.text: This bracket can be used to mount stick-on LED strip lights around the hotend. It attaches between the extruder heatsink and fan, thus also serves to fill that gap and stabilizing the fan. It's intended for 50mm x 10mm LED segments. Some soldering skills required. The hole is intended to allow routing the power wires to the underside. As seen in the pictures, I used a 12v strip, which is directly connected to the power supply. I also secured the wire with a zip tie. The LEDs in the picture are 5630 warm white lamps, which may be on the bright side. I might add a dimmer to tone them down a bit. (the underside of my cooling duct is covered with aluminum foil tape, as is the top where it's in close proximity to the hotend - this LED mount has plenty of clearance from the hotend) This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6z6IvD0ZVfg

Anet A8

comments.text: My leds flicker when hotbed turns on :-(  do You have any solution for that ?
comments.author: porlock

comments.text: Sounds like you're on the edge of what your power supply can handle, I'd be extra cautious that you're not overloading it to the point that it could fail (perhaps spectacularly).  Maybe upgrade the power supply, drive the LEDs from a different power source, reduce the number of LEDs, maybe add a resistor inline to reduce the current draw through the LEDs.  Good luck.
comments.author: porlock

comments.text: What do You think about add a electrolytic cap in parallel to the led circuit ?
comments.author: aw_

comments.text: It's possible that could reduce the flickering, but it's probably going to draw even more current when the cap is charging and it ignores the problem that you may be pushing the power supply too hard.
comments.author: porlock

title: altoids fishing kit "sunfisher"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Altoids Fishing Kit "sunfisher" 1.0 is just what it sounds like. I wanted to design a little fishing reel that is 100% printable and can be packed down into a standard Altoids tin. I got this idea while backpacking in the mountains; I stopped to camp next to a gorgeous
little stream for the night and thought (insert thought bubble here): “I wish I had a small packable fishing pole so I could pull one of these trout out of the water for dinner”. As the 1.0 might suggest, this is the first iteration of the design and may evolve over time. The reel is a basic hand crank spool with a small trigger that functions as a friction break for the drum. I find that casting works best if I pay off the line at my feet first and flip-cast the bait with both hands. Use 4” zip ties (that slip right into the tin with a couple of my favorite flies) to fix the assembly and the eye guides to a long flexible branch or piece river cane, and away you go!

Printer:

prusa i3 custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.30 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I printed all the parts in ABS with .30 mm layers and 30% rectilinear infill. The outside drum and the crank handle will need to be printed with support. Tip for the bolts and nuts - I didn't have good luck printing just one bolt at a time. A tall thin part like that didn't cool much in between layers, so by the time the print was halfway done my nozzle was just stirring around gooey plastic. Now I print two or three bolts at a time to give the layers more time to cool and I get much better quality thread definition.

The nut and bolt hardware was developed using the Nut Job Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647. This is some particularly brilliant work; check it out if you haven't already. It's important to note that Nut Job is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Share Alike. Thus the nuts and bolts for the Altoids Fishing Kit should be considered under that license as well.

Step 1: Get Everything Together Print ONE each:
  • inside drum
  • outside drum (with support)
  • top bracket
  • bottom bracket
  • drag trigger
  • crank handle (with support)
  • m7.5 bolt
  • m8.5 nut
  • m9.5 bolt
  • m10.5 nut
    • Print THREE each:
  • line guides
    • Gather Up:
  • 4" zip ties (small ones pack up in the tin better)
  • fishing line
  • flexible stick, branch or cane pole
  • fishing tackle to suit your needs
  • epoxy or solvent glue
    • Step 2: Assemble Clean up any chaff and scaling from the printed parts. Glue the inside and outside drum halves together with a bit of five-minute epoxy or solvent glue. Take care to keep any glue from getting into the center hole of the drum. After ample drying time, line up the two bracket parts, the drum part, and the crank handle and bolt this together with the long bolt and larger nut. Depending on how the nuts and bolts printed you may have to gall the threads slightly so the nut will stay in place (the way a nylon lock nut stays in place on a bolt without spinning freely) with all the spinning and cranking. You want the parts to be snug enough so the crank handle will stay seated securely into the depression in the outer drum but loose enough that the drum isn't bound up. Use the shorter bolt and smaller nut to fasten on the drag trigger (see pictures) so that
    the bump on the trigger part can engage the lobes on the rim of the inside drum part. Now grab that branch; use a long, thin, green branch that's about as thick as a magic marker at the base. Use a couple of those zip ties to mount the finished assembly to the pole. The bracket has 4 slots for zip ties, but I have found that 2 will work just fine. Starting at the tip of the pole, space out the line guides and strap them on with one zip tie each. It should be looking like a real fishing pole now. Feel free to use as many guides as you want but at least 3. Take a little time to make sure the insides of the eyes get a once-over with a jewelers file or some sand paper to remove any burrs that might chafe at the line. I had thought that the line guides would benefit from some acetone vapor smoothing, but smooth is the goal so approach as you see fit. Spool on some line and get to fishin'. Note: The brackets will make a reel that cranks with the right hand. if you are a left-hand cranker, you'll want to mirror the top and bottom bracket parts.

UPDATE 1 update #1, I added 2 new drum parts. The "inside drum large spool" and the "outside drum large spool". These parts are dimensionally similar to the original parts, with the exception of having a 30mm diameter spool. This will hold less fishing line tan the original parts "inside drum" and the "outside drum" but add the benefit of reeling line in faster which makes the whole reel more functional. A larger drum should also have a less dramatic curling effect on the monofilament line. Also it was suggested in the comments to increased the depth of the crank handle indention in the outer drum. I have incorporated this change in the "outside drum large spool" as well.

comments.text: That is an interesting point. I am a cad designer by trade and wouldn't come to work if I didn't get a paycheck. I also like being part of a 3d printing community where there is a free exchange of ideas and designs. Everyone appreciates getting paid for their efforts but I have also used plenty of other peoples work for free so I guess I can see both sides of the topic. I suppose I'm glad that thingiverse has incorporated voluntary tipping of designers for their models but I don't mind letting people use my designs without paying. comments.text: I have gotten a good result with galling the threads, ever so slightly, with a pair of pliers. This seems to add a bit of resistance and prevents the nut from spinning freely (the same way a nyloc nut would work). You might also try to print the nuts at 99% or 98% so that you could get a tighter fit. I think a metal bolt and nyloc nut would also work well and be an inexpensive solution.

title: IKEA Lack cabinet for 3D printer and other things or machines

description.text:
Had the wonderful idea of a custom cabinet for my 3D printer. Size is to high for regular Lack, so I will extend the feet with the feet from the second LACK.
Results in 2-level-cabinet. Printer is up, below some filament or other things will find place. uses
  • LACK table
  • FISKBO picture frame in 50x70mm (also available in 40x50)
    • 50x70:

    103.003.76 green
    502.979.61 black
    603.003.74 white
    903.003.77 blue
    302.979.62 pink

    40x50:

    403.003.89 green
    502.956.55 black
    003.003.86 white
    203.003.85 blue
    302.956.61 pink

    a few connectors (from sheet metal or some of the nice things on thingiverse) to connect the tables to each other what you'll need: 2 hinge per picture frame to get doors or 4 edge caps to screw it fixed on the sides and not to open.

Ich habe mir überlegt, meinen 3D-Drucker in eine Vitrine zu stellen. Aufgrund der Bauhöhe reicht der normale LACK Tisch nicht aus, der muss mit abgesägten Füßen verlängert werden.
Kürzt man die verbliebenen Stümpfe noch weiter ein, so ergibt sich dann eine Vitrine mit 2 Ebenen, oben den Drucker und unten diversen anderen Krempel, der dazu gehört. Um die Vitrine seitlich rundherum zu schließen bietet sich der Bilderrahmen mit PVC-Einlage an. Die Bauhöhe des Rahmens ist gerade mal 12mm, es kann keine Scheibe zu bruch gehen.

Modified the method of the click mechnism to a less fragile. Both options of clip and hinge available for download. 2017-01-09 New Clip models. According to the preferred position of the hinge mount and same height of the side panels the clip had a bad position at the point of the screw. Very nearly to the bottom of the table top is not a good place to drill a screw into. round about 3mm higher is a better place for that. hinges and clips to the left, equal to bottom right position (like rotation of 180°) hinges and clips to the right, equal to bottom left position (like rotation of 180°) total distance of cabinet top to the bottom: 803mm distance between the hinge base center to center: 769.15mm History

2016-12-31
added a set of hinges for both sides all in one. first version (image preview) were only 140 degrees to open, these are full 180 degrees free.

2017-01-07
Clip & Hinge modified

2017-01-08
Clips und Scharniere nochmals bearbeitet.
Die Lasche zum einrasten war stets zu steif, habe sie schrittweise dünner gemacht und dabei gleich den Abstand zum Körper vergößert, damit das ganze nicht beim Druck wieder zu einer Form verschmilzt. Denn dann bricht die Lasche erst recht weg. Sie steht nun mit einem Winkel <90° auch leicht schräg zum Unterteil, damit die Lasche auch sicher hinter dem Haken rastet und nicht hochsteht und deswegen die beiden Teile nicht zusammenhält. Den Rest erledigt das Gelenk an sich.
Damit die Bohrungen auch leichter und mit weniger Druck zueinander passen, hab ich noch 0,1mm Spalt zur Entspannung zwischen die beiden Fügeteile vorgesehen. Und das was mein Drucker jetzt mit 0,3mm Layer rausgelassen hat, passt schonmal recht gut zusammen. Clip & Hinge modified again
gave the upper clips flap a little bit more flex by making it thinner, what increases the distance to the main block that it would not stuck together at the print process. And I applied a litte bit direction downwards, that it is a little bit inclined now - an angle below 90 degrees.
And between the clip upper and lower part there is 0.1mm gap got it printed a few times with 0.3mm layer. the flap was really stiff, it broke always (what is forced by the layers) now it would fit like I prefer it has to

description.header: hinges and clips have got same modifications, that they are equal (except the movement feature)
description.text: Use the helpful drilling template to set same hole positions to the lack table. Suitable to hinge and clip base mounts.

2017-01-21
I was wondering why my re-designed clips did not fit to the frame: had not made a change of the width from 20.3mm to 21.3mm.
Both clip models now corrected.

2017-01-24
While I build my cabinet I've seen that the horizontal and vertical distance of the clip corners is a little bit to low. Thought it was happen because inaccuracies of the lack table-constructions (feet cut with a saw e.g.), but it is a failure of the measured dimensions of the frames.
Need about 1 to 1.8 mm at all.
But the holes are in the table right now. The template I wanted to leave so.
So I shift the screw holes of the clip near to the centre of the frame to move the clips in direction to the corner The hinge blocks will become 0.925mm less height from both sided, because the frames hinge is very tight to the blocks. So they will stay in place and give the hinge a little bit more space to move. Upper edge is 0.925mm lower only to keep symmetry. Notice: If you have printed the template yet and want to use it (you are free to lay the cabinet itself on the floor, lay the frame onto the cabinet and shift it by hand to centre align the frame and screw it without a template) you will need to reprint the clips.
If you want to use your previous clips and a template ask for a new template-stl. Assemble Instructions After you assembled the lack tables to the cabinet use the drilling template to mark the points where the screw mounts the clips or the hinge on the table tops. Prepare the picture frame to become a clear window. remove the paper shields and the protection foil from the plastic sheet Insert the plastic sheet to the frame use a paperclip to connect the clip and hinge parts together. you can use e.g a dowel pin with diameter of 1mm not movable frame as an always closed window screw the clips to the cabinet and put the frame to the clips, close the clips. First: after mount the hinge base install the hinge on the frame and put the lower corner to the base block. Second: insert the pin to the block and then put the picture frame to the upper part of the hinge close the hinge clips together. now you can close the door additional information: inner width is 564,4mm. When I use the laser measure tool it tells ~568mm

description.text:
This is a simple smartphone/tablet stand with modeled plastic M4 plastic threads. I made a wider version to fit the tablets more comfortably although the small one is capable of holding a 9.7" iPad 3 even in portrait mode (check the pictures).  
It was a bit difficult to fill the prevoius version with weight so I separated the three holes with small chambers to make the filling easier. I used lead from a damaged diving weight - those balls are tiny, heavy and fills the weight chamber quite precisely.

comments.text: It's just standard small (~2-3 mm) lead balls used by fishermen. BTW here is v2 without weights (not neccessary even with a 9.7 iPad): https://www.youmagine.com/designs/tablet-stand-v2

author: danieljames1

description.text: Print-rite DIY fan bracket for 50mm fan.

Printer:

Print-rite DIY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

,2

Infill:

30%

Notes: Needs
2 m3 x 10mm screws
1 50mm squirrel cage fan The fan is glued to this bracket with cyanoacrylate glue. I currently have this fan powered in parallel with the extruder fan.

comments.text: Wow. With the new blower fan installed and wired up to a constant 12v, my hotend never makes it to temp anymore. I have to set it to 210 (my new max temp) in order to get a model sliced at 205 to print. The fan is kicking the snot out of the hotend all the time. I PID tuned it and everything!
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: I've had good luck letting the slicer decide when and how much to have the fan on.
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: That would be great if there was a way to do that. I'm plugged into the cooling fan port (middle of the three on the bottom left of the board), but it never does anything less than 12v. I've tried changing slicer settings and I've manually turned the fan speed up and down using the terminal. It's always wide open.
Run the hot end fan off of 12V and the cooling fan from the fan output.
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: How has this been working for you so far? Most of the cooling fans I see have an outlet very close to the nozzle. This one is angled correctly, but is up a ways from the print bed. Have you noted any change in performance between this design and the other style of part cooling?
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: Thanks for your comments. I don't have anything to compare to as this is the only cooling I have used but its worked for me. The air is directed in a stream just below the tip and the "squirrel cage" fan provides more pressure than axial fans do. I have noticed the hot end temp drops when the fan is turned on hard  but only a degree or two and it comes right back up.  I didn't like how bulky other designs looked as I want to keep additional weight on the Y axis as low as possible. The only issue I've had was the fan driver of the controller wasn't turning on all the way. This meant the hot end cooling fan wasn't ever running at full speed and adding the additional fan didn't help. I ended up replacing the driver transistor with a MOSFET.
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: WOW! This is amazing. I saw that hole in the aluminum block and thought "Huh, this is weird."
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: how did this turn out for you, i am interested in printing this :D
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: It's been working well for me. As a bonus, I zip tied the extruder wires to the top of the fan to keep them neat. I've been contemplating insulating the extruder nozzle though.
comments.author: rbcmptrmn

comments.text: It fit a little bit funny, but was an excellent solution for mounting a fan once I wedged it into place. 10/10, all things considered.
comments.author: rbcmptrmn

comments.text: Is there something I should change?
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: No, I don't think so. It was probably the PLA I was using that caused my trouble. I never reprinted this with better quality plastic because I was able to get my first one to fit, so I don't have enough data to tell you to change anything. Mine worked when all was said and done.

title: Boxty: Desktop Robot Friend (Pan and Tilt with Pixy, Webcam, and Laser)

description.text:
Boxty is your desktop robot buddy! He'll sit at your desk being cute, and maybe useful! In his head is a Pixy camera, allowing him to track a colored object or marker. There's a laser in his mouth for zapping things, and he has a webcam in his eye that could be used for facial recognition or other machine vision applications with RoboRealm, or you could use it to Skype your friends, or have a unique camera for Twitch streaming! Boxty uses:
  • 2 x RobotGeek 180 Servos (https://www.robotgeek.com/rg-180-servo)
  • 1 x Pixy CMUcam5 (https://www.robotgeek.com/pixy-cmucam5)
  • 1 x RobotGeek Webcam (https://www.robotgeek.com/robot_webcam)
  • 1 x Geekduino (https://www.robotgeek.com/robotgeek-geekduino)
  • 1 x RobotGeek Sensor Shield (https://www.robotgeek.com/robotgeek-sensor-shield)
    • And you can power Boxty with:
  • 1 x 7v5a Power Supply (https://www.robotgeek.com/7v5A-power-supply)
    OR
  • 1 x 7.4v Lithium Ion Battery (https://www.robotgeek.com/lithium-ion-battery-7-4v-2200mah.aspx)
  • 1 x Battery Wiring Harness (https://www.robotgeek.com/battery-wiring-harness)

description.text:
This is a remix of Cyuls Filament guide (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1445480).
I have added a base for a filament length counter. I am using the ABS Digital Fishing Line Length Counter (http://www.ebay.com/itm/182027750390?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT) I hade to put some tape, twisted to be double sided, in the bottom of the wheel of the counter because it was to slippery against the filament.
I am thinking about greating my own wheel that will give a better grip to the filament. I dont say that this gives an exact count of filament, I havent measured it yet. The signature I added is to give some more stability when the filament yanks the counter. It works nice for me but as i said, I am not saying it counts 100% correct. :)

author: Flodanilsson

description.text:
I needed an upgraded spool spindle and thinking ahead I knew I needed one that could handle any size spool that I could potentially run into.  I used 1" od by 3/8" id flanged bearings that I got locally at the hardware store and they snap in snugly.  I would recommend 3/8" threaded rod, but all I had on hand at the time was 1/4" so that is the bushings in the picture.  Jam nuts will be needed on the static position support cone and and the adjustable cone needs to slide freely.  
The printed jam nut (knob) isn't necessary of course, a regular nut would work just fine, but I thought a knob keeping the same look would look neat and be a little less cumbersome.  If using 3/8" threaded rod I would just drill the knob out and cut threads in the print.  On the 1/4" rod I ended up having epoxy a 1/4" nut onto the knob because the print came out just a tad to big and was a little to loose.
I printed mine in PETG and it has held up well so far.  I would recommend printing it with a high infill, especially if using PLA.  Also, I wouldn't torque it down to tight as it isn't necessary and just lightly snugged up does just fine.  If you don't have good layer adhesion tightening it too much could snap the claw fingers off.

author: electronhacks

description.text: I saw this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12560 the other day and thought it looked like something that my sister would enjoy. It didn't seem to be standard size cupcake size though and thought I could refine on the idea some, and add a little style to it. It should make standard size cupcake cups. Also I raised and rolled the upper edge, hopefully enough that the paper doesn't tear as it slides across. Somehow while I was designing it I realized it was starting to look like a crown, thus the name the Cupcake Queen press. (Update 12/30/2016) After Printing it I realized there was some tweaking needed to be done. The way I had tapered the bottom in the original version wasn't letting the paper pleat enough. In V2 I have deepened the pleats all the way to the bottom.

comments.text: Very attractive design, nice work.
comments.author: rssalerno

comments.text: What size exactly is "standard"?  I mean I already know... I'm asking for a friend... and feel silly for having to tell him.
comments.author: ReaperNo1

comments.text: Haha, a full size cupcake. To site http://www.webstaurantstore.com/guide/629/types-and-styles-of-baking-cups.html "Typically, standard baking cups measure 2" x 1 1/4" and are commonly used for traditional-sized cupcakes or muffins." So now your friend can know too :)
comments.author: ReaperNo1

description.text:
i've printed the extruder upgrade for my rep2, but after some prints i got some problems with filament, the pla warms and warped so the spring tension can't pull out the filament right as before. i printed also in abs but even the same problem. i didn't buy the upgrade from Makerbot, so i test some prints with mod and this is the best i've done. i've just print for a couple of week and prints are excellent! the mod consist to put a M3 nut in the left hole (right if you want to print for lefty), so the screw is more solid and the arm doesn't warp the PLA base.
i've put also a small m3 washer between the base and the arm, and taped (kapton) the extruder motor between the motor and the extruder base to keep lower the temperature. Have fun!

Simple bracket for mounting a 240W Power Supply (12V 20A 240W model S-250-12 Eccanixity purchased from Sourcingmap on Amazon UK). The power supply has four M3 threaded holes spaced at about 84mm x 126mm. The bracket is secured to the 20x20 extrusions on the printer with an M4 screw and nut, and the power supply attaches with M3x6mm screws (one at the top should suffice - the lower hole may be hard to access from inside the printer).
These brackets leave 5mm clearance between the PSU and the printer, which is enough to clear a 220mm heated bed, and also provides some space to fit a cover over the mains voltage connections.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness

Infill:

25%

comments.text: Hi, do you have a photo of how this looks mounted? Thanks!
comments.author: siddharta

comments.text: I don't have a photo, but the "L" faces outwards, and the rounded tip points up, so the two small rectangular protrusions fit into the 6mm channels on the two lower 20mm extrusions, then a single M4 screw and nut is used to secure the bracket through the middle hole to the upper extrusion (slide the brackets left and right in the channel to line up with the PSU holes), and a short screw through the top-most hole of each bracket goes into the PSU. The ventilation holes in the PSU face outwards and upwards.

This is a power switch box made for the Milled/Printed 3D Printer (MP3DP) PrusaI3 style. You can find the MP3DP here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1524754. This box mounts to existing screws on the MP3DP.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: Support material is designed into the print to minimize support material used. See Post-Printing instructions.

This is designed with support structures for bridging. There is a thin bridge layer under the overhang for the holes to print on. After printing this layer is removed. The thin triangle support near the hole on the end can be cut off. Before support material is removed. After support material is removed. Switch Wiring Note the switch orientation. In this picture the switch the wide spaced terminals are at the bottom. Before you insert the switch into the assembly, note the location you plan to install the assembly and position the switch so ON is up. Wiring so switch light is on when power is on: Solder a short jumper from the fused Line terminal to one side of the switch. Solder the jumper to on of the terminals that are spaced closest together. Solder a wire to the wide spaced terminals, on the same side. This wire will go to the L terminal (Line) on the power supply. Solder a short jumper wire to the other close spaced terminal. This wire can be a smaller wire because it just caries the load of the internal switch light. This wire will connect to the unfused terminal. In addition use a second wire, solder both to the unfused terminal. Connect this second wire to the N terminal (Neutral) of the power supply. Solder a ground wire to the ground terminal and connect this to the ground terminal of the power supply.

description.text:
Replacement handle for files.
Printed with dual extruder, soft TPE over PLA or PETG cores (an attempt at printing with an ABS core failed). Designed for files with a tang roughly 8mm wide at the root, 45 to 50mm long and tapered in both width and height. In practice the handle is a bit tight - I might try heating the tang to see if I can get the files to sit a little deeper. The temperature needed to soften the plastic should be well below anything that might affect the file's hardness.

Printer:

Home made

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20% or so seems to be fine

Notes: The TPE needs to print slow and with plenty of cooling. Printing over PLA is the easiest because the temperatures of the two plastics are similar, and the PLA tolerates the cooling fan without any problems. I find PETG finicky to print at the best of times and using it for dual extrusion seems to make things worse. The upside is the elasticity of PETG allows the handle to get an excellent grip on the tang of the file. The TPE grip was supposed to be 2mm thick but seems to have come out a little more than that. I was printing the grip with a 0.9mm nozzle and 1mm extrusion width and Slic3r added a gap fill line between the two perimeters. The core was printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.5mm extrusion width. Some of the handles were printed with 0.2mm layer height and others with 0.3mm - both worked fine. I haven't used the handles long enough to know how well they will last. They feel great in the hand, but I may have gone a little on the skinny side at the narrowest point.

Designed in onshape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/258d5b5c206bbe57f8004480/w/085d64410ba6c5bcced032b4/e/cc5b3a734e45fefe297b0a11

title: Pyramidal staircase maze
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Sometimes, life is like this pyramidal staircase maze :) Maze generator is my first challenge of using OpenSCAD to generate a maze automatically. After that, many mazes were created. Some people were curious about how to implement these mazes. They were, actually, all based on Maze generator. There are many different maze algorithms. If you are interested in them and want a beginning, a book I recommended is Mazes for programmers. Honestly, maze algorithms are not very difficult. If you come from imperative languages, the hard part of using OpenSCAD to implement a maze may be the paradigm of functional programming. The code of Maze generator is quick and dirty because it's my first challenge of using OpenSCAD to generate a maze. From that time, I've studied OpenSCAD for one year. One day I thought, how about rewriting the maze to test my understanding in OpenSCAD? The code of Pyramidal staircase maze contains the basic implementation of a maze. While writing it, I considered readability and added more comments in the code. Hope this would be helpful if you also want to implement one by OpenSCAD. Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.
  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

You can find the MP3DP here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1524754 When mounted to the MK8 extruder, the ring gets in the way of the cooling fan shroud. Once the mounting ring is attached, the LED lights are attached to the mounting ring with the double sided sticky tape that comes with the LEDs. Add the extender is added to the fan shroud mounting tab. I have included a picture that shows the extender location. remixed_from.author: devlab
remixed_from.title: Battery holders for AA and AAA types

description.text:
VIDEO



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2AyXv0sG1v4

SUMMARY



These Glasses are remixed off of a model by vespahon called Calgara PRIMO and are the first pair in their series of glasses. My modification to the glasses adds holes for LEDs and a trench to run wires in. The purpose of this remix is to create a pair of safety glasses that are combined with a head lamp in order to provide light when working in dark places.



Frame



Modifications

The modifications I made to the frames where simple. Holes where added to both top corners in between the edge of the frame and the hinges to hold LEDs. Two holes where also added to the bridge. In between the holes a narrow trench was added to hide wires that run in-between the LEDs.

Printing

I found the best way to print the frame is shown in the photo. Printing the frame this way gives you the maximum detail on the trench that runs in between the holes. You also get to print without supports. This file also has a lot of small details, so I recommend printing it at a lower layer height. The frame needs to be sturdy, but it doesn't have to be solid since it is only going to be resting on your nose. I recommend printing around 35% infill.

Post Printing

To assemble the frame the arm needs to fit in the grove and the pin needs to slide in from the top. When I printed my models neither of these worked. I had to file the grove larger and drill out the holes so the pin would fit.









Arm





Modifications

The only thing that was needed to be done to the arm of the glasses was to add two holes. These holes are used to mount the battery case to the arm of the glasses, but only if you are using BatteryCase.stl or Old_Battery_Clip.stl.

Printing

When printing the arms I found the easiest way to get the part to adhere to the build platform was to lower the model in the slicing software just past the platform and then slice it. Unless you can print at a 45˚ angle supports will be necessary to print the bent end of the arm. Again there are small details on these files so a small layer height should be used, I used 0.2.

Post Printing

After printing there was some rough edges where the support was touching the arm. That part of the arm would be resting on the ear, so I sanded it down after the support was broken off. The holes that the battery case would attach to were also drilled out.






Battery Case








Design

The battery cases were designed in Google Sketchup then re-exported using Meshlabs to fix all the errors that Sketchup is known for. There are two versions of the Battery case. BatteryCase.stl is made to fit in the holes in the modified arm while BatteryCase_Glue.stl is designed to be simply glued to the side using super glue or your choice adhesive. If you chose to use BatteryCase_Glue.stl you don't have to print the modified arm, the original can be used instead.

Printing

These models don't have to be printed at an extremely low resolution because there is not much detail. Support is needed to print BatteryCase.stl because of the pegs that stick out of the bottom.

Post Printing

To prepare the battery case two bolts and two nuts are needed. The bolts are used to push against the batteries and make the electrical connection while the nuts are used to tighten against the wire and hold it in place. To finish the post printing the battery case can be glued or snapped onto the arm.



Old Battery Clip





Modifications

This battery clip designed by devlab was modified by making it extremely small and adding two pegs that come off the bottom and fit into the holes on the modified arm.

Old?

Printing this battery clip at such a small scale works, but makes it extremely fragile. The two that I printed broke, so I didn't use them. I printed them in PLA so I don't know if they would hold up better if they where printed in ABS. I included the file incase someone wanted to try.






Wiring





Parts Needed

Parts needed:
  • 5mm LEDs
  • Large gauge solid wire

    • Wiring

    The LEDs are inserted into the holes and the wires go from the battery case and are soldered to the first LED. The wires are then extended to the other three LEDs one at a time putting them in parallel.



    Final Thoughts





    Files

    The files for this project are not perfect, and you may find simple errors in the meshes or scaling. Feel free to share them with me so I can fix them for later versions.

    Uses

    These glasses where designed for the main purpose of illuminating your work surface when working in the dark. While constructing them I thought of many other thing that could be done with them like:
  • Party glasses (if you use blinking RGB LEDs)
  • Anti-camera glasses (if you use infrared LEDs)
  • And even better yet a no hands cat toy (if you use lasers)

    • Enjoy Printing

description.text:
I was looking for a "jewel" for my daughter's cosplay, but all the diamonds on Thingiverse were "complete" diamonds... I wanted one with a flat bottom to glue onto another flat surface... and the STL Meshes I was able to download / customize wouldn't easily edit...
So, I took the SCAD script from "takuya" (thanks btw), and simply got rid of everything below the z plane, making it flat.  The script works identical to the original, and you can customize as you like, but you'll only get the top of the diamond, not the point.

Designed a simple 4 station dock to just keep the batteries and micro pen organized and clean. Easy print with minimal infill.  Made for the G pen micro and similar micro pens.  I accounted for shrinkage of ABS in the file but feel free to upscale 1% to allow for more tolerance.

author: frankkevinwalsh

description.text: I've long thought that a vape in the shape of a tobacco pipe would be cool, as the form factor of a vape has little to do with the function short of being a container. I've looked around for a while for a vape that is in the shape of a pipe, but could not find one for a reasonable price, and have yet to find one locally in my small town. So here is what I have designed. It is designed around the 18350 rechargeable lithium battery (slightly more than half the height, same diameter, around half the charge capacity). This is a work in progress, as it does not have a receiving slot for a lithium battery charger, and no easy way to mount a tank to the stem. I am leaning towards a spark fun lithium battery usb charger circuit: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10217 and a 14mm diameter run of the mill tank. Again, this is a work in progress. I welcome any recommendations, or even requests in the design. When it is at a reasonable state of completion, I will release the openscad file and change the cc license to public domain. Thanks for any feedback.

title: Camera Bed Mount - Logitech C920 on Wanhao Duplicator 6/Monoprice Maker Ultimate

description.text:
Remix of an already nice mount design, but for a C920 on Wanhao Duplicator 6/Monoprice Maker Ultimate bed. The cameras are only "10 off" but the mounting system is quite different. I combined the c920 universal webcam mount design with the c910 bed mount. 
Hint for remixing: MeshLab can load .STLs and export to Collada and Sketchup can import Collada as manipulable objects. Just remember to explode them.
It works, but the angle adjustment range isn't great. It is just good enough for a good view of the bed, but it takes very little for the camera to want to point upwards. I don't think this thing is meant to be mounted at this angle. I hate you Logitech.
Still planning on testing and improving this design. Perhaps make it look less ugly. I would also like to make a version that would fit inside with the optional door closed if possible. Adding the other screw down design is something I have in mind as well.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

20

Notes: One side is flat to prevent extra supports. Also has the nice side effect of offsetting the camera towards the center.

comments.text: Looking at the other remix source, wow, yeah, the C920 mount really makes your life difficult.
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: I have just been concentrating on the mount for now. Other than removing the supports I haven't really changed your original much. I only really did that because of print time and extra material. I do think they add an aesthetic quality. Using the clip because it is easier to get on/off to mess with. Plus I don't have the hardware for screwing it on yet. It seemed to stay in place during its first test print, but bumping or pretty much any tension on the cable other than gravity would point the camera who knows where. I'm thinking I need to angle the back brace in about 45 degrees. The range of motion of the camera mount is good, but the whole thing needs to be pointed down a bit more.
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: Hmmm, you know, we could put a clip on the mount - route the USB cable through the clip so it holds it in place and that way you can move the cable at the end and not throw off the camera. That would at least help with that. When I had the camera mounted to the frame with gaffer's tape, I looped the cable and taped it down so movement in the end of the cable was isolated from the camera.
comments.author: Nbachman

comments.text: I made a newer version that actually tucks in and would JUST clear a door, and it uses the front bed leveling screw to secure the camera. I think it wouldn't translate exactly to the 920, unfortunately, but might be an idea.
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: Very Nice. I might be able to work with that, but it looks pretty tight in there already. I have been debating just stripping the camera down to just the circuit board so it is smaller and easier to work with.
comments.author: cmh

comments.text: I'm not 100% sold on the new center mount because of glare issues... and if you wanted to fit the camera behind a door and angle it at all, yeah, I think that's what you'd have to do. All the extra junk of the outer case would just make it get in the way. Breaking it out of that and having just the board and functional parts might be a good approach.
comments.author: Nbachman
